question_stem: The graph of \(y = g(x)\) has a minimum point at \((3, -2)\).

parts.question_text: State the coordinates of the minimum point of the graph of \(y = g(x) + 5\).
parts.solution_text: The transformation \(y = g(x) + 5\) represents a vertical translation of the graph \(y = g(x)\) upwards by 5 units.  Therefore, the minimum point of \(y = g(x) + 5\) will have the same x-coordinate as the minimum point of \(y = g(x)\), but the y-coordinate will be increased by 5.  The original minimum point is \((3, -2)\).  Adding 5 to the y-coordinate gives \(-2 + 5 = 3\).  Therefore, the minimum point of \(y = g(x) + 5\) is at \((3, 3)\).
